definition: to catch a turtle in a jar (idiom); to set oneself an easy target/a turkey shoot
pottery container for water, wine etc
variant of 甕|瓮[weng4]
surname Weng
variant of 甕|瓮[weng4]/earthen jar/urn
to hit (the mark)/to be hit by/to suffer/to win (a prize, a lottery)
within/among/in/middle/center/while (doing sth)/during/(dialect) OK/all right
China/Chinese/surname Zhong
to clutch/to grab/to capture
freshwater soft-shelled turtle
variant of 鱉|鳖[bie1]

sentences.english: And in prison in an ambush waiting for a sure catch.
sentences.chinese: 并在监狱里设下埋伏等待瓮中捉鳖。

sentences.english: At 36 I've enjoyed the fish in a rather small barrel too.
sentences.chinese: 36岁了，我享受了很多瓮中捉鳖的时光。

sentences.english: I'm 45 and getting women now is like shooting fish in the proverbial barrel.
sentences.chinese: 我今年45岁了，现在找女人就跟瓮中捉鳖一样。

definition: lit. like a turtle in a jar/to be trapped (idiom)
lit. even given wings, you couldn't fly (idiom); fig. impossible to escape
to walk right into the trap
lit. to pull a snake from its hole/to expose a malefactor (idiom)
lit. please Sir, get into the boiling pot (idiom)/fig. to give sb a taste of his own medicine
to coordinate outside and inside offensives (idiom)/(fig.) to act together
to beat sb at their own game (idiom)
lit. to guard a tree-stump, waiting for rabbits (idiom)/to wait idly for opportunities/to trust to chance rather than show initiative
to lure the tiger from its domain in the mountains (idiom)/to lure an enemy away from his territory
to prepare an ambush/to waylay
to defeat the enemy by capturing their chief (idiom)
the mantis stalks the cicada, unaware of the oriole behind (idiom, from Daoist classic Zhuangzi 莊子|庄子); to pursue a narrow gain while neglecting a greater danger
pinyin: tang2 lang2 bu3 chan2 , huang2 que4 zai4 hou4

definition: to threaten the east and strike to the west (idiom)/to create a diversion
see 連鍋端|连锅端 [lian2 guo1 duan1]
lit. beat the grass to scare the snake (idiom)/fig. to inadvertently alert an enemy/to punish sb as a warning to others
inescapable net (idiom)/trap/dragnet
